Award.AwardTitle: Methods for the analysis of population-genomic data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The advent of methods for economically sequencing entire genomes has ushered in the field of population genomics. Although whole-genome sequencing harbors the potential to yield estimates of population-genetic parameters with unprecedented accuracy, the methods essential to the analysis of data have lagged behind greatly. The proposed work will develop a general statistical framework for the analysis of population-genomic data. The general strategy is to derive and computationally validate a set of efficient estimators for population-genetic parameters at three levels: individual genomes; multiple individuals within populations; and multiple populations. Specific subprojects include the measurement of patterns of variation and covariation among nucleotide sites, levels of population subdivision, and the development of novel methods to facilitate genome assembly and the refinement of genetic maps. Considerable emphasis will be focused on the development of efficient estimation algorithms for use by the genomics research community.

These methods will be widely used in both applied and basic research. Special attention will be devoted to identifying optimal sampling strategies, including the tradeoffs between depth of sequence coverage per individual and numbers of individuals, and between length, number, and quality of reads. As a consequence, the resultant methods should enable investigators to harvest the maximum possible information from their existing data sets, while also promoting the future design strategies to maximize informational yield per unit sampling and sequencing effort. The software to be developed will be permanently housed and freely available at the National Center for Genome Analysis Support, and workshops will be held to assist the user community in the implementation of such tools. The Plant Genome Research Project is co-funding this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

The advent of methods for sequencing genomes in economically feasible manners ushered in a new era of population genomics, yielding the potential to generate estimates of the genetic features of populations with unprecedented accuracy. However, the methods for the rigorous analysis of data have lagged behind, with many investigators relying on inefficient and biased ad hoc methods that make arbitrary assumptions about read error rates and employing minimum sequencing coverage levels that unnecessarily discard valuable data. Substantial challenges in diploid species are also incurred by the random sampling of the two parental nucleotides.

               The goals of the proposed work were to develop a general set of statistical procedures, in a maximum-likelihood (ML) framework, for the analysis of population-genomic data that transcends species and sequencing platforms, and to apply these methods to existing data sets as proof of principle. The general strategy was to derive and computationally validate a set of estimators for a diversity of population-genetic parameters, in each case striving for methods with minimal bias and sampling variance. Three highly desired attributes of the methods developed were abilities to: 1) correct for random and incomplete sampling of parental alleles without requiring arbitrary cutoffs for sequence coverage; 2) eliminate the need for external estimates of sequence error rates; and 3) provide a logical framework for evaluating hypotheses with likelihood-ratio test statistics. 

               Estimators for a wide array of population-genetic parameters were pursued at three levels: individual genomes; multiple individuals within populations; and multiple populations. Specific subprojects involved: 1) the measurement of nucleotide diversity, linkage disequilibrium within and among individuals; 2) the evaluation the distributions of allele frequencies (the site-frequency spectrum) across the genome; 3) the measurement of levels of population subdivision and local inbreeding; and 4) the development of a method to estimate the history of past population sizes from information contained in a modern-day sample.

               Given the enormous computational demands of population-genomic data, emphasis was also focused on development of efficient algorithms for likelihood-surface estimation and on identifying optimal sampling strategies, including the tradeoffs between depth of sequence coverage per individual and numbers of individuals, and between length, number, and quality of reads. These design strategies provide a basis for maximizing informational yield per unit sampling and sequencing effort. Although read lengths will become longer and coverage levels deeper as future technology developments arrive, the proposed methodology is meant to be platform independent, thereby requiring no structural modifications in the face of such changes. All methods developed on this project have been incorporated into a statistical package made freely available to the general public.
